answers.author: Brent Stockwell
answers.text:
This is an excellent question, and although we have discussed this subject a lot in Scottsdale over the years, I have to admit we haven't set out to develop a good definition of what constitutes (and what does not constitute) "policy." Although this is over ten years old, I have run across a good resource from Washington MRSC that might be valuable to you as a starting point. Take care and we're interested in what you come up with.  http://www.mrsc.org/Subjects/Governance/legislative/policyoradmin.aspx

answers.author: Robert Nanni
answers.text:
A policy is a guiding principle,  agreed upon values, which in local governments  are established by the elected body. The policies are supported by processes and procedures designed and incorporated into operations by management staff.

answers.author: Susan Robinson
answers.text:
Over the years and in a variety of local government and school settings I've found the following to be a useful definition of, and distinction between, policy and procedure.  
A policy provides guiding principles setting direction for the operations of the local government. A policy reflects and specifies the desired outcomes of the governing body. Policies provide the framework needed to coordinate and execute the jurisdiction’s activities and help to focus attention and resources on high priority issues, aligning and merging efforts to achieve the goals of the Board or Council. 
Procedures are the operational processes required to implement the Board/Council direction. Procedures are often a series of steps to be followed to accomplish the desired end result. The manager implements the governing body’s policies through various procedures; they can be formal or informal, specific to a department or applicable across the government. 
Together policies and procedures can clarify goals and desired outcomes and provide staff responsible with the direction and consistency they need to successfully improve processes. A policy describes "what" the governing body wants accomplished and “why”.  It is generally expressed in broad terms, address major issues, require Board/Council action and therefore change infrequently.  Procedures describe processes, “how”, “when” and sometimes “who” will implement the policy.  They are often very detailed and may change frequently in response to changing conditions. Procedures are changed with approval of the manager and generally do not require action by the governing body.

answers.author: Susan Thorpe
answers.text:
Thanks everyone for your excellent definitions and your help. Our Council agreed upon the following, which includes policy decisions and administrative decisions to assist in distinguishing the role of Council from the role of the Manager. 
Public policies are the particular goals and directions of a local government.  Common examples include community growth, land use development, strategic planning, and capital improvement and financing.  City Council policy decisions focus on the purpose, services, and programs necessary to achieve the council’s goals and objectives.  Policy provides a high-level overall plan to achieve adopted goals and objectives.  A policy will often contain the 'what' and 'why'.
Administrative decisions provide for the effective, efficient and equitable implementation of the policies approved by Council.  They align the local government’s administrative systems with the values, mission, and policy goals defined by the community and elected officials.  Administrative tasks are the responsibility of the City Manager and they include establishing practices and procedures to implement adopted policy as well as the oversight of daily operations.  Implementation will often contain the 'what', 'how', 'where', and 'when'.

answers.author: [Unknown]
answers.text:
It is like a road map set by the City Council as representatives of the citizens. It is sometimes difficult, since some members of Council want to take the shortest and quickest roads even thought they are toll roads. Other Council members want to take the scenic and slower route. Truthfully both roads get there it just depends on the route the majority decide to take.

author: Susan Thorpe
text:
I am interested in your organization's definition of policy as it applies to the realm of decision making of elected officials. We are in the process of creating council subcommittees and want to be clear that they deal with POLICY rather than operatioal or administrative matters. (i.e., trying to distinguish between policy and administration roles). I appreciate any defiinitions you have that help your council and staff in this area.  Thankyou.
Susan Thorpe
Deputy City Manager, Peoria AZ
